intro: Rubus hirtus var. ferox, commonly known as the bristly blackberry, is a deciduous shrub native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that ripen to a dark purple or black color. Its flowers are typically white or pale pink, and it thrives in moist, woodland habitats. It is often found in the understory of forests and along stream banks.
